children.subject:
Along with what other tips people have said, you can try to see if you can get in on a professors research group meetings, by asking the professor, students, etc. in the group.

Also from my limited experience, if you email a professor, many will still respond, sometimes you have to try a few times.

Mood, I have been looking for research for a while, but no one really responds. Kind of sad. But does anyone have tips on how to get a response? I feel like so many people are successful with this, but I can't figure it out apparently.

Sadly I worked with a professor’s grad student all summer and did research that led to writing a paper to be submitted and I still was told by the professor that they couldn’t advise me :(

Luckily since then I’ve found another professor but just sharing cause it’s really hard out there so don’t feel bad if the first time doesnt work out

I think cold emailing professors wont get you much success. 

I would recommend already having a great relationship (aka already working on a project with the professor/one of their grad students) before asking about 5th year master sponsorship. 

Now to get the initial research you can go to office hours, cold email grad students (they are more likely to respond to emails than profs), apply to urap, things like that.

Also, if a professor likes you but isn't a good research fit for some reason, they can probably introduce you to other professors (in a way where they'll actually listen). This is actually how I met my current PhD advisor.

Note that profs tend to get bombarded with emails, and often won't pay attention to or read a cold email. Even grad students might not.

In office hours however, they're much easier to reach. It depends on the class, but often the professor or grad student will have nearly empty office hours. This is especially true if the professor refuses to answer homework/coding questions in OH. 

When I took 188, there were around 500 people in the class. I went to Anca's OH almost every week, and I don't think I ever saw more than 3 other people.

As a TA, I've also had many OH's in which I didn't get a single student (usually when no homework was due that week), even though there were >150 students in the class, and only a couple hours of content OH.

OH gets really boring without people to talk to (at least for me), so professors and grad students will often be happy to talk with you about concepts, research, etc, if you show up.

You should confirm with Michael Sun, but from what I've heard, any EECS professor can advise. Not sure if non-eecs profs are allowed, but if you want to work with one, you should be able to work something out with an eecs professor such that they're nominally your advisor but the non-eecs prof actually advises you.
Is there a list of professors that can be advisors for 5th year master? Also advisors for 5th year master have to be from the EECS department?

history.content: How do we find a research advisor before applying next year? Ive emailed professors but dont get responses. Also, what is the acceptance rate to this program?
history.subject: 5th years masters
